review.title: Maximizing Non-Monotone DR-Submodular Functions with Cardinality Constraints
review.abstract: We consider the problem of maximizing a non-monotone DR-submodular function subject to a cardinality constraint. Diminishing returns (DR) submodularity is a generalization of the diminishing returns property for functions defined over the integer lattice. This generalization can be used to solve many machine learning or combinatorial optimization problems such as optimal budget allocation, revenue maximization, etc. In this work we propose the first polynomial-time approximation algorithms for non-monotone constrained maximization. We implement our algorithms for a revenue maximization problem with a real-world dataset to check their efficiency and performance.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In this paper, we present the first polynomial time approximation algorithm for the problem of maximizing a decreasing return submodular (DR-submodular) function under a cardinality constraint. Submodular functions appear in various contexts, such as machine learning tasks, sensor placement problems, sections is graphics, plant location and sentence coverage issues [Nemhauser et al., 1978]. The inherent feature behind all these problems is that they all have a decreasing return property. In addition, the decreasing return property may occur in applications where we do not make a binary decision on a number of elements. For example, we look for a specific budget among media channels (such as TV, newspapers, websites, etc.) in order to maximize the impact on a number of potential customers.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: In contrast to the problem of minimizing submodular functions (comparable to convex minimization), which can be performed efficiently [Schrijver, 2000; Iwata et al., 2001], the maximization of submodular functions is NPhard, since it includes the well-known NP complete Max Cut problem. Classical work by Nemhauser et al. [1978] showed that the greedy algorithm has an approximation ratio of 1 − 1e for maximizing a monotonous, submodular function under a cardinality constraint.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed two polynomial time-fit algorithms for non-monotonous DR-submodular function maximization under a cardinality constraint: one has an approximation ratio that depends on k (on the cardinality constraint), and the other algorithm has a constant approximation ratio (in expectation). We have demonstrated the efficiency of our algorithms through an application in revenue maximization. metadata.abstractText: We consider the problem of maximizing a nonmonotone DR-submodular function subject to a cardinality constraint. Diminishing returns (DR) submodularity is a generalization of the diminishing returns property for functions defined over the integer lattice. This generalization can be used to solve many machine learning or combinatorial optimization problems such as optimal budget allocation, revenue maximization, etc. In this work we propose the first polynomial-time approximation algorithms for non-monotone constrained maximization. Our first algorithm achieves an approximation ratio of (1 + 12 ‖B‖1 √ k(‖B‖1−k) )−1, where B ∈ R represents the limit for each coordinate of the function and k is the parameter of cardinality constraint. This ratio is maximized when k = ‖B‖1 /2 and evaluates to a (1/2)-approximation. Our second algorithm is a random greedy algorithm that gives a (1/e)-approximation ratio in expectation. We implement our algorithms for a revenue maximization problem with a real-world dataset to check their efficiency and performance.
